note: Core weapons only. For vehicle hacking, drone operations, corporate escalation, and electronic warfare, see the full Wire & Chrome supplement.

vehicles.name: Corp AV
vehicles.desc: Corporate aerial vehicle. Armoured, autonomous-capable, and branded with the logo of whatever megacorp owns the skyline tonight. She carries executives above the traffic, the pollution, and the people who'd kill them for their shoes.
vehicles.notes: The corp AV is your cyberpunk helicopter. She represents corporate power — literally above the streets. Use her for VIP extractions, corporate raids, and the dramatic moment when the megacorp sends an AV to collect someone important. She's also a status target for street-level characters.

vehicles.name: Street Racer
vehicles.desc: Illegally modified, running pirated firmware, and fast enough to outrun corporate security on the neon-soaked highways. She's built in chop shops from stolen parts and driven by someone who considers traffic laws a suggestion made by people who can't drive.
vehicles.notes: The street racer is your player vehicle for cyberpunk street campaigns. She's customised, personal, and probably illegal. Her speed comes from software hacks that override safety limiters — which means she's fast until the hack crashes.

vehicles.name: Tactical Drone
vehicles.desc: A small autonomous platform carrying sensors, a light weapon, and the cold algorithmic judgement of whatever AI the operator uploaded this morning. She scouts, she surveys, and when authorised she kills — all without risking a human operator.
vehicles.notes: The tactical drone is your surveillance and light combat tool. She extends the operator's senses into areas too dangerous to enter. She can be hacked, jammed, or shot down. Use her to scout ahead — and to create the paranoia that drones watch everyone, always.

vehicles.name: Merc APC
vehicles.desc: Mercenary transport. Armoured against small arms, carrying a squad of hired killers, and bristling with non-lethal and extremely-lethal weapon systems depending on what the contract specifies. She's the tool of private military contractors who are technically not an army.
vehicles.notes: The merc APC is your corporate muscle delivery vehicle. She arrives, the doors open, and professional violence ensues. Use her for extraction teams, corporate security responses, and the moment when the players' heist triggers a military-grade response.

vehicles.name: Spider Tank
vehicles.desc: Six legs, an autonomous weapons platform, and the casual disregard for civilian safety that comes from being piloted by an AI with a corporate ethics package. She climbs buildings, she straddles streets, and she represents the moment when law enforcement became a military operation.
vehicles.notes: The spider tank is your cyberpunk boss vehicle. She climbs walls, she's nearly invulnerable to small arms, and she's probably operated by an AI that doesn't negotiate. Use her for the corporate escalation that makes street runners realise they've gone too far.

vehicles.name: Courier Bike
vehicles.desc: Electric motorcycle with encrypted cargo compartment and a dead-man's switch that wipes the contents if the rider's biometrics go offline. She carries data, biological samples, and anything else too sensitive for wireless transmission through a city full of hackers.
vehicles.notes: The courier bike is your delivery mission vehicle. She carries something important from A to B through a hostile city. The cargo is unknown to the rider — which creates moral tension when they discover what they've been carrying.

vehicles.name: Armoured Riot Van
vehicles.desc: Corporate security's crowd control vehicle. Water cannon, acoustic weapons, tear gas dispensers, and armour rated against improvised weapons. She's designed to suppress civil unrest without killing anyone — officially. The non-lethal weapons have a lethal setting that nobody talks about.
vehicles.notes: The riot van is your oppression vehicle. She appears during protests, strikes, and civil unrest. She represents corporate control of public space. Use her as both enemy and tool — the players might face one or steal one.

vehicles.name: Hover Limo
vehicles.desc: Anti-gravity luxury vehicle. She floats above the gridlocked streets, carrying whoever can afford to ignore traffic with the rest of the city's problems. Tinted windows, armoured hull, and a minibar. Because even in dystopia, someone's doing fine.
vehicles.notes: The hover limo is your wealth vehicle. She represents the gap between the corporate elite and the streets below. Use her to establish setting tone — the limo floats overhead while the players wade through street-level filth. She's also the target for any heist involving a rich mark.

vehicles.name: Cargo Drone
vehicles.desc: Autonomous delivery platform. She carries packages from warehouse to doorstep without human interaction, navigating urban airspace alongside thousands of identical units. She's the backbone of the delivery economy and the perfect vector for smuggling.
vehicles.notes: The cargo drone is your mundane infrastructure that doubles as a tool. Hack one to deliver contraband. Hijack one for surveillance. Crash one into something as an improvised weapon. She's everywhere and nobody notices her, which makes her useful.

vehicles.name: Security Sedan
vehicles.desc: Corporate security vehicle disguised as a civilian car. Armoured panels beneath the paint, run-flat tyres, and a sensor suite that identifies threats before the occupants know they're in danger. She looks like everyone else on the road. She isn't.
vehicles.notes: The security sedan is your undercover corporate vehicle. She blends with traffic until the moment she doesn't — lights activate, weapons deploy, and the civilian disguise is gone. Use her for corporate tails, ambushes, and the reveal that the car following the players isn't civilian.
